reviews.review_text: Long story short, the game is a lot of fun. Short story long, if you hate lego games there is nothing for you here. If you hate lego games and are a fan of DC comics, you MIGHT find this game enjoyable as it does delve heavily into the DC worlds. Now here are my thoughts on the PROS and the CONS:  PROS: -Voice acting is top notch -Fun with friends -Ton of content -Every character felt like they were treated with love and care as they each have their own unique reticle unlike Lego Batman 2 where all the side characters had a generic reticle.  CONS: -Listening to Conan O'Brien can be annoying as he repeats himself every 10 seconds -Story is not the best -Repetitive gameplay (as expected with all lego games) -The free roam worlds felt empty and lacking the emersion of Gotham from Lego Batman 2  OVERALL: -Great game 8/10

I bought Lego Batman 3 during the christmas auction. It was a steal and I am glad I did. However, I wouldn't advise you to pay full price just yet.   Batman 3 is the sequel to Batman 2 (duh) and shifts the series' focus further from Batman and more onto the Justice League and the DC universe in general. It also extists purely to not fall behind on Marvel because all the gameplay additions made in Lego Marvel over Batman 2 can be found copy pasted into three. Anyway, the regular production values from Tales give a good show. The evil Brainiac has come to Earth to shrink it and to collect it. He kidnaps the seven Lantern corps leaders and uses them to power his beam weapon. Up to the heroes to stop him. Once again you punch and puzzle your way through the DC galaxy collecting bricks, figurines and powerups to stop Brainiac.   The thing plays like a lengthy cartoon episode and is certainly fun when played with a partner. Be it your sibling, offspring or spouse. The selection of characters is considerable, with virtually every franchise providing at least five representatives. Unfortunately, the powers and abilities are all pretty much standard fare by now. Nothing really new is introduced from Marvel. Some characters feel downright lacking (lantern corps can't even light a dark room. LANTERNS!) Still, it is a funny game to buy and play at a discount. Especially if you're a comic buff. The game likes to reference its own past even includes Adam West from TV.  Unfortunately, it reeks of bad business practices. The main menu greets you with a wealth of DLC that can be unlocked for rather unreasonable prices. Most packs contain about 20 batmans and a single stage. Not much to write home about, so you can do without.

I love the inclusion of Batman Beyond characters and the massive worlds where you can search for new character tokens, golden bricks and costume peices can lead to many, many hours of play and if anything, this game got me to re-watch Batman Beyond: Return of the Joker after I finished it, though I disliked their portrayal of Brainiac where in the second game the hint for Brainiac was kind of intimidating where as in this game he's every two dimensional villain who only wants to bottle up worlds and not digitise them into information like the real Brainiac...despite attempting to do that to the main characters who attack him.  It's still worth a playthrough though, but only on cheap with all the DLC giving you access to many different and fun characters to play as in free play mode.

Lego Batman 3: Beyond Gotham is another great adition to the Lego series of games and features a vast amount of characters as per usual. With this being DC we have the return of other previous characters from the previous title and the known DC universe as well as new characters. The story is very well constructed yet I was dissapointed on the portrayal of Braniac when comparing him to the DC comics and films.   Credit goes to the designers as they have carefully inserted lesser knwon but amazing characters with great backstories as well as witty little remarks and jokes that in some cases only the die hard DC fans will get. Although the gameplay is fun and you'll get hours out of the game there is the case of replay value and repetition. Freeplay offers around another 8 hours of play depending on the player and is even better with a friend but as with most Lego games there is repetition which deters players after a while.  Having played the game thoroughly and completing it several times I was very pleased with the time I spent on the game, there are some features that could do with looking at or improving but not by much. Despite these very small issues I would definately say give the game a go. In my opinion it's a solid 8.5/10

I've an affinity for many of the Lego Games, most especially the Lego Marvel Superheroes game, which happened to have the best combination of open world with smooth controls, hilarious dialogue, and just looked sweet!  Batman 3 Beyond Gotham iterates on the system. I've played/own a ton of Lego games, and I gotta say that with Batman 3, it's really apparent how TT's matured much of their control scheming and gameplay 'modes'. Comparitvely, flying is a lot smoother than it was in Batman 2, and I think they've taken a lot of the critical feedback to heart and really optimized the game well. I haven't had many frame stutters, and I'm running max settings all around.   I really appreciate the suit changing system too, which in Batman 2 involved you finding a suit changing station. That was pretty tedious to say the least, but Batman 3 makes it much more fun by allowing players to switch to the various suits at any time simply by holding a button down (Y, if you use an X360 controller).  I haven't spotted any errors/glitches, and I haven't touched Open World yet, but if it's anything like it was in the Marvel game, it's gonna be awesome. Really, I'm only a few hours in, but already I can see myself repeating my gameplay for a long time! Looking forward to seeing TT fold these new iterations into the next Marvel Superheroes 2!

Seeing how this game came 1 year after TT game's big seller Lego Marvel Super Heroes you thought they would have learned a thing or 2 about what people enjoyed in lego games.  But apparently not.  I guess a part of it comes from not being very set-in on DC characters since the characters i know i can probably mention on my fingers.   But what mainly did it for me was the overall dull look.  The DC movies and pretty much everything has often been dark toned and tried to be cool and taken very very seriously. Which means it translates poorly into lego worlds. It means the world just become awefully dark but without any sort of cool or interesting feel to them, it just makes the maps dull. The main hub you're left at too is something that's bad.  While Lego Marvel Superheroes had a whole city to run around in with vehicles to choose and go around in and special levels to play through gates that you make with golden blocks, this game gets a space station. One that you can't even fully explore. Yeah, it got like 6 rooms in total. Actually, if you've played Lego marvel super heroes, let's say it this way. Imagine only being able to run around the helicarrier. That's what the space station is like.  It has other worlds you can travel to,like the hall of heroes which is really just 1 room, with a hidden path that leads to the legion of doom, which is again. 1 room. They do give you all the lantern planets to play on, which sounds cool. Until you play them.   These planets are so damn small, and so lacking of anything interesting that it's almost interesting how they managed. Not only are they a pain to walk on, (can't find a good way to describe it. Just look it up on youtube or something) they also give you the moon to play on. Which is pointless, there's nothing to do there. Except find portals to the lantern planets, but you can fast travel to them via your map which you carry around. Sooooo...  The biggest offender of worlds though, must be the damn green lantern planet. This is the ONLY MAP IN THE WHOLE GAME THAT YOU CAN USE VEHICLES ON.  And do you know what it is? JUST A BIG GREEN EMPTY ROCK WITH A FEW RACES THAT YOU CAN DO JUST AS WELL WITH CHARACTERS RATHER THAN VEHICLES.  I thought the lego games were going to be interesting, but i was wrong. I completed this game to 100% like i do all my lego games, and while i sunk only 40 hours into this, it felt 3 times as long as Lego marvel super heroes, because that time i had fun, this time i didn't. I thought lego jurassic world was the worst offended of all lego games but no, this by far is.  They even nerfed the combat. You heard that right. The big characters, they nerfed them. I remember playing them alot in Marvel super heroes because they were strong and easily dispatched groups of enemies in seconds, but this time, no attacks they do can target more than 1 enemy. Now, you might say ' But that's just so people won't use an OP character ' which would be fair. IF THEY DIDN'T HAVE GOD DAMN SUPERMAN IN THIS WHICH IS THE VERY DEFINITION OF OP.  I really can't see anyone have much fun with this game, it feels rushed and overall dull.  I do have to give it credit for bringing in Adam West as voice and character to find and rescue, but he's no  Stan Lee  so to say, even if he on his own is a great person  The most fun i had with this game was whenever Mr. Mxyzptlk was on screen, because of all people. They choose Gilbert Gottfried to voice him, in a KIDS GAME. Sure he doesn't swear but, really?! Pretty much anything that guy says is ment to offend someone, so just hearing his voice is cracking me up because i hear curse words and offensive jokes just by hearing his voice even if he don't say them in this game. That's just hillarious.

LEGO Batman 3... What to say about this game but: It's a LEGO game. That says a lot actually, though this one stands out a bit further than the rest. But first, let's start with the story; It slowly starts with Batman and Robin kicking crime's behind as usual, until a supervillain by the name of 'Brainiac' captures the lanterns to possess their power to shrink planets down to pocket-size and keep it in a bottle... At least Lex Luthor wanted to be president... Anyway, Batman, The Justice League, and some of the known villains go on a mighty mission to stop Brainiac from shrinking Earth.  Now the graphics: This new LEGO game does it's best to look spectacular at it's highest, whilst staying optimised for older compters, I never not liked the graphics of LEGO games, and much like most of their playsets, they are more innovative with each generation. Of course, it does suffer from motion-blurring and lighting. The lighting seemed to be more blinding than pretty. Anyway, it plays, that's what I care about.  Gameplay: As per usual, smash, smashy-smash. But more smash than puzzles, half of the time I was stuck because I didn't think to destroy this crate, or this random structure. Plus, working out the controller settings is a pain in the neck. Worse than someone slapping your sunburn. It works a few minutes in and suddenly, it decides not to let me play! Though it is easily solved it's just annoying.  What I call 'Suit-Centres' or 'Suit-Dispensers' (the things where you'd change suits for different occasions) aren't in the game anymore, instead you have a 'Bat-Tastic Gadget Wheel'. They actually call it that. Either way, suits in your pants and I'm not complaining. It, too, works.  Occasionally you'll run upon some bugs: one I find particularly annoying is when moving diagonally: the character walks instead of runs, when most segments require you to go diagonally, you'd walk, resulting in getting smashed, or falling to your inevitable demise, oh well, it's a small problem. There is a pretty wide arrangement of characters to unlock, over 150 characters supposedly, but you'll only get a handful playing the story. Also Conan O'Brien is in this, I don't know why, or how, but he is.  Speaking of the story, it is slow, and too slow to keep my attention until later than half-way through.  Characters: Here I go trying to say if the acting is good, frankly, I don't know what makes a good voice actor, but I'll try. There is some extremely good talent behind the characters, the actors did what they do, and that is: bring life to these personalities we love so dearly, and some we hate, I'm looking at you Aquaman. Either way, talent!  Overall: I do like this game, not quite love, but like. It just has a few qwerks, the story is so long! Six hours in and nearly at the end, hopefully. The walking bug, fix it! It works in other games why not this one? Okay, enough blabbering, I give this... 8/10 Recommend IF you really want to get it. The price is a bit high, but thank goodness there was a sale at my store.  It is a treasure to have amongst the other LEGO or even Batman games, and if you like lego, and the old batman sets, you'll love this game.

I have Lego Star Wars Saga, Clone Wars, Indiana Jones, Lord of the Rings, Marvel Super Heros and Batman 1, 2 and now 3. I am about halfway through Batman 3 so far and its been alot of fun. Its a solid game and runs well on my computer. My only complaints are the lack of free roam and the levels seem a little long and drawn out. I am an Adult and its kinda funny. I get weird looks from my friends when i tell them to check out the lego games, until they actually see the game. We are all huge comic book fans and they are shocked when they see how many characters are unlockable and how great these games are. I love that Batman 3 included a Batman 1966 level and i admit i am kinda rushing through the game to unlock it. Its not the best Lego super hero game, i'd have to give that to Marvel, but its worth the price and will keep you entertained for hours!

If you know any of the previous LEGO games, you know exactly what to expect.  Graphics and sound deliver what they are expected to- surroundings and characters look fine and the music includes licensed tunes from official TV- and movie soundtracks. Nice, but nothing raelly outstanding.  The reason to play LEGO games is the gameplay and that is so addicting that you just keep coming for more. So I was really happy to see that the levels felt longer and overall better designed in this game than its predecessor.  The downside is well known: hardly anyone seems to like the multiple hub worlds. I don't see the 7 lantern planets as actual level hubs, as neither of them actually connects to any level or, any other world than the moonbase (which in turn becomes a hub for the planets). Actually, there are only two real hubs: the space station and the moonbase, with no less than 9 additional areas to explore. Sounds great, but becomes tedious as none of these areas are interconnected. All in all, a big step down from LEGO DC Superheroes and LEGO Lord of the Rings with their enormous overworlds.  On the other hand, the side quests are fun and sometimes form small story-arcs (or rather, arcletts) wich can be quite funny. The variety of the quests is great and I could have done with quite a few more.  All in all, a solid instalment of the LEGO series that offers more of the same- not yet stale, but lacking fresh ideas.
